Award.AwardTitle: LSD1 reprograms epigenetic memory to enable changes in cell fate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical explanation

In 2001, Dr. David Allis proposed that small chemical modifications in the packaging of DNA could form a code that affects the expression of genes. Since then, an intense effort has been underway to understand what these different modifications do and how they affect the biology of organisms. Previously my lab provided evidence in worms suggesting that these modifications can be stably inherited from cell to cell as cells replicate themselves. These experiments will determine what happens to this information as genes are passed from parents to offspring in mammals. In addition, this research will determine whether or not the information contained in the packaging of DNA can influence the information encoded in the DNA itself. By understanding these basic biological mechanisms, this work has the potential to shed light on the cause of a broad range of diseases, from birth defects to autism. All of the experiments will be carried out in partnership with undergraduates from the nearby Oglethorpe University, under the guidance of Oglethorpe professor Dr. Karen Schmeichel. These students, many of whom are minorities and/or first in their family to go to college, have no access to research using mice, the preeminent human model. Therefore, providing these students with the opportunity to participate in this research has the potential to profoundly impact their understanding of science and scientific research.

Technical description

Two of the most fundamental parts of the existence of multicellular organisms are (1) the ability of cells to maintain their cell fate, and (2) how cells undergo changes in cell fate during key developmental transitions. To accomplish this, cells must be able to (A) faithfully transmit patterns of gene expression through mitosis and (B) change transcriptional patterns during developmental transitions. However, the mechanisms that control these processes are currently unknown. To investigate these mechanisms we will use a mouse model of the histone demethylase LSD1/KDM1a to determine the function of this enzyme during (1) the gamete-to-embryo transition and (2) in testis stem cells. Through these experiments, we will (A) determine whether histone methylation can function as a transcriptional memory in mammals, (B) investigate the relationship between histone methylation and DNA methylation and (C) determine the function of LSD1 in regulating cell fate. By providing a potential paradigm shift in our understanding of how histone methylation functions to maintain cell fates and how this histone methylation is regulated during cell fate transitions, this work has the potential to highly impact our understanding and treatment of a broad spectrum of diseases, from birth defects to autism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

(1) The paternal role of LSD1 in the differentiation of testis stem cells

In the male germline, we discovered, along with the Kimmins Lab, that LSD1 functions to decommission the stem cell program during testis stem cell differentiation (Myrick et al. 2017, Plos One). This was part of broader work showing that LSD1 functions this way in all stem cell populations. 

During the process of investigating LSD1 in the male germline, we discovered a problem with the germline Vasa-Cre allele, where deletion of a floxed allele in the germline of the parental generation initiates a transvection event that silences the undeleted floxed allele and prevents recombination (Rodriguez et al. 2017, Genetics). This is only the second known example of transvection in mammals. Remarkably, we subsequently discovered that by simply inserting an extra generation between the first and second crosses in the mating scheme, we were able to circumvent the transvection event. This not only allows the mouse community to use the Vasa-Cre allele, but it also provides a new model for studying the mechanism of transvection in mammals.

(2) The maternal role of LSD1 in the gamete-to-embryo transition at fertilization

In the female germline, we discovered a new paradigm where incomplete reprogramming at fertilization leads to inherited phenotypes that manifest later in development (Wasson et al. 2016, eLIFE). Additionally, while investigating the maternal role of LSD1, we generated allele specific assays for a large number of imprinted genes in a B6/Castaneus F1 hybrid background. These assays were published as a resource paper for the community (Wasson et al. 2018, G3: Genes, Genomes, Genetics). The new paradigm that we presented in our eLIFE manuscript led us to propose that epigenetic reprogramming at fertilization is a susceptibility point where rare mutations in histone reprogramming enzymes combine with genetic background and environment, such as maternal age, to give rise to neurodevelopmental disorders. Examples of neurodevelopmental disorders in which defective maternal reprogramming may contribute include Kabuki Syndrome, caused by mutations in the H3K4 methyltransferase and the H3K27 demethylase, as well as rare LSD1 patients. 

Broader Impacts:

The NSF-supported collaboration between the Katz laboratory and Oglethorpe University has significantly influenced the Oglethorpe Biology curriculum and has resulted in indirect ?ripple effects? throughout the institution. Rather than implementing a single semester Course Embedded Undergraduate Research, we reasoned that students could develop their research sensibilities more fully by receiving training in multiple courses, with increasing intensity, staged throughout their undergraduate career. Such a developmental approach would allow all graduating Biology majors to have a high-quality, authentic research experience to add to their scholarly accomplishments. Over the past 6 years, we established a Pipeline CURE curriculum, where biology majors at Oglethorpe take part in C. elegans research reiteratively throughout the biology major (http://source.oglethorpe.edu/2017/05/08/what-a-worm-is-worth/). These broader impacts were conceived and executed with Dr. Karen Schmeichel, chair of the Oglethorpe Biology Department and subcontractor on the NSF grant. 

Implementation of the Pipeline CURE also set the stage for yet another major innovation in our broader impacts: a capstone CURE course. In this capstone CURE course, students perform research, related to the research in my lab at Emory, over an entire semester. As a result of the capstone CURE course, ~30 students engaged in authentic research over the last 3 years, with some of the research contributing to a publication that is currently in revision. This also resulted in the first four senior research theses in the 182-year history of Oglethorpe University. Additionally, beginning almost three years ago, the administration undertook a fundraising campaign to support our efforts (https://source.oglethorpe.edu/2017/11/08/cousins-center-science-innovation-receives-600000-local-philanthropic-foundation/), and last year the University completed a full renovation of the biology building, designed specifically to enhance the Pipeline CURE (https://progress.oglethorpe.edu/projects/w-ike-cousins-center-science-innovation/). The newly renovated space includes a separate C. elegans laboratory (accessible by students 24 hours a day) outfitted with all of the necessary equipment for every Capstone CURE student to carry out senior thesis research. Long-term, our goal is to have every student who participates in the Capstone CURE course be given the opportunity to conduct original thesis research at Oglethorpe. In this way, NSF funding has the potential to have an even more substantial broader impact by creating the foundation for sustained authentic research opportunities at Oglethorpe University.
